citations.narrative:
One enclosure housing two Black and White Ruffed Lemurs, located near the Sloth enclosure, had two exposed electrical
wires that the animals could reach. One was exiting the back of the nest box while the other was connected to a fan with
an extension cord. In the same enclosure, the back of the next box had 3 exposed nails and another on the elevated
platform. All electrical cords and exposed nails were outside the enclosure but within reach of the animals.
Another enclosure housing two Black and White Ruffed Lemurs, currently away from public view, had an exposed
electrical wire within going down to the nest box. Exposed nails and electrical cables that are accessible to the animals
could result in injury posing a significant health risk. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be kept in good repair,
and they must protect the animals from injury. Correct by 1/19/2023.

During inspection, the Coatimundis and Sloth enclosures had items that could result in animal injury:
-The enclosure for two Coatimundis contained an unstable elevated platform and two exposed nail heads. The platform
was approximately 2x4 feet and was supported by one wood post in the center. At the end farthest from the door, a
perching log was pushing on the platform causing it to tilt. When the Coatimundis would walk on this area, the platform
would give significantly. Two exposed nail heads were seen on each end of the platform. The platform being unstable and
the exposed nail heads could result in animal injury.
-The enclosure housing two Sloths contained a space heater with an exposed electrical wire that was accessible to the
animals. Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals as they could chew or pull on them.
Unstable platforms, exposed nail heads, and live electrical wires in enclosures may result in animal injury. The facility
must be structurally sound, constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved, and
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by 1/26/2023.

During inspection, areas in need of cleaning were found in the commissary. Along the wall in the corner adjacent to the
small refrigerator contained several deceased small roaches and debris. A large deceased roach also was found on the
window sill adjacent to the small refrigerator. Inside the small refrigerator, too numerous to count deceased flies/gnats
were found and there was blood and debris on the bottom shelf. The large refrigerator contained too numerous to count
deceased flies/gnats, blood on sealed fish packages on the door, and a large amount of blood on the bottom of the
freezer section. Failure to effectively clean the commissary has led to the attraction of pests, could lead to contamination
of food which may result in animal disease. Supplies of food and bedding shall be stored in facilities which adequately
protect such supplies against deterioration, molding, or contamination by vermin. Correct by January 19, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
One enclosure housing two Black and White Ruffed Lemurs, located near the Sloth enclosure, had two exposed electrical 
wires that the animals could reach. One was exiting the back of the nest box while the other was connected to a fan with 
an extension cord. In the same enclosure, the back of the next box had 3 exposed nails and another on the elevated 
platform. All electrical cords and exposed nails were outside the enclosure but within reach of the animals.  
Another enclosure housing two Black and White Ruffed Lemurs, currently away from public view, had an exposed 
electrical wire within going down to the nest box. Exposed nails and electrical cables that are accessible to the animals 
could result in injury posing a significant health risk. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be kept in good repair, 
and they must protect the animals from injury. Correct by 1/19/2023. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
During inspection, the Coatimundis and Sloth enclosures had items that could result in animal injury: 
-The enclosure for two Coatimundis contained an unstable elevated platform and two exposed nail heads. The platform 
was approximately 2x4 feet and was supported by one wood post in the center. At the end farthest from the door, a 
perching log was pushing on the platform causing it to tilt. When the Coatimundis would walk on this area, the platform

would give significantly. Two exposed nail heads were seen on each end of the platform. The platform being unstable and 
the exposed nail heads could result in animal injury.  
-The enclosure housing two Sloths contained a space heater with an exposed electrical wire that was accessible to the 
animals. Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals as they could chew or pull on them. 
Unstable platforms, exposed nail heads, and live electrical wires in enclosures may result in animal injury. The facility 
must be structurally sound, constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved, and 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. Correct by 1/26/2023. 
3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
During inspection, areas in need of cleaning were found in the commissary. Along the wall in the corner adjacent to the 
small refrigerator contained several deceased small roaches and debris. A large deceased roach also was found on the 
window sill adjacent to the small refrigerator. Inside the small refrigerator, too numerous to count deceased flies/gnats 
were found and there was blood and debris on the bottom shelf. The large refrigerator contained too numerous to count 
deceased flies/gnats, blood on sealed fish packages on the door, and a large amount of blood on the bottom of the 
freezer section. Failure to effectively clean the commissary has led to the attraction of pests, could lead to contamination 
of food which may result in animal disease. Supplies of food and bedding shall be stored in facilities which adequately 
protect such supplies against deterioration, molding, or contamination by vermin. Correct by January 19, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
